pullRequest.body:
Linear programs over a general `Module` with constraints given in the form "aᵀx - b ≥ 0" and the objective function as an `AffineMap` to be minimized.

---

Zulip discussion:
https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.237386.20Linear.20Programming

Four PRs incompatible with each other:
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7386 (list of constraints)
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9693 (matrix form)
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10026 (Antoine Chambert-Loir's def; semirings, linear)
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10159 (Antoine Chambert-Loir's def; rings, affine)


<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Alternative: #9693
Another alternative: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10026
This looks fine, but mathlib isn't a huge fan of definitions without any lemmas about them. Are there any low-hanging results that you can seed the file with?

```suggestion
  /-- (possibly not a) matrix of coefficients -/
  A : (n → K) →ₗ[K] (m → K)
  /-- Right-hand side -/
  b : m → K              
  /-- Objective function coefficients -/  
  c : n → K                
```
with better descriptions

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion b : m → K /-- Objective function coefficients -/ c : n → K ```
Martin, this is a worst-of-both-worlds choice that is halfway between your proposed matrix-only version, and my vector-space-only version. I suggest reverting to your initial version.

This should be:
```suggestion
/-- Linear program in a more versatile form. -/
structure SomeLP (K : Type*) {V : Type*} (P : Type*)
    [LinearOrderedField K] [AddCommGroup V] [Module K V] [AddTorsor K P] where
  /-- Equality constraints -/
  eq : Finset (P →ᵃ[K] K)
  /-- Inequality constraints -/
  le : Finset (P →ᵃ[K] K)
  /-- The objective function -/
  obj : P →ᵃ[K] K
```

so that it actually works on affine spaces. Note `V` is deliberately implicit as it's found via `AddTorsor`
This should be generalized to `SomeLP K P` to match the above
working on it!
Currently `e x` and `i x` don't typecheck.
See my suggestion below: you want `x : P` not `x : V` (but now you have two `P`s and need to rename one)
Ah, thank you!

Whoops, I think I meant
```suggestion
    [LinearOrderedField K] [AddCommGroup V] [Module K V] [AddTorsor V P] where
```
(which says `P` is an affine space whose vectors are `V`)

```suggestion
    (lp : SomeLP K P) : Set P :=
```

```suggestion
def SomeLP.solutions {K V P : Type*}
    [LinearOrderedField K] [AddCommGroup V] [Module K V] [AddTorsor V P]
```
the type arguments can be inferred from `lp`
I think there might be a nice way to state this using `IsGreatest`, perhaps `IsGreatest (lp.objective x) (lp.objective '' lp.feasibles)`.

TODO using
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/60c0549c0f4066236400ae680319233691ce584c/Mathlib/Order/Bounds/Basic.lean#L66

```suggestion
def linearProgram_of_equalities_inequalities_objective
    (equalities inequalities : List (P →ᵃ[K] K)) (objective : P →ᵃ[K] K) :
    LinearProgram K P where
  constraints := inequalities ++ equalities ++ equalities.map Neg.neg
  objective := objective
```
I don't like name collisions (even if they get automatically resolved in the right way). Is it really necessary to make the collision here?
There's no collision to speak of here, so I don't understand your objection.
When I see `objective := objective` it takes me a longer time to realize that the first `objective` is the field and the second  `objective` is the argument.

Well then you'll love the fact that Lean has builtin syntax for this, `{ objective }` as a shorthand for `{ objective := objective }`!

I think that ship has well and truly sailed.
Can I use `{ objective }` here?
You might be able to use `{objective, constraints := _}`
This probably doesn't belong in `Matrix` any more
What directory do you recommend?
Possibly just the same path with `Matrix` dropped.

The naming convention doesn't allow `_`s here. Perhaps the shorter:
```suggestion
def LinearProgram.mkOfEqs
```
You should add a proof that `(mkOfEqs eqs ineqs obj).feasibles = { x : P | (∀ a ∈ lp.eqs, a x = 0) \and (∀ a ∈ lp.ineqs, 0 ≤ a x)}`

```suggestion
lemma feasiblesLinearProgram_superset_of_constraints_subset {lp₁ lp₂ : LinearProgram K P}
```
and below
You should add an API lemma immediately after this which expands `x \mem lp.feasibles` to the statement about `constraints`.
You mean `LinearProgram.feasibles_mkOfEqs` up by one item?
And the lemma `feasiblesLinearProgram_superset_of_constraints_subset` should come before defining `LinearProgram.MinAt` as well?
No, I mean a lemma proved by `Iff.rfl` that is currently missing, which says what `x \mem lp.feasibles` means
Oh.

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma LinearProgram.mem_feasibles {lp : LinearProgram K P} {x : P} :
    x ∈ lp.feasibles ↔ ∀ ⦃a⦄, a ∈ lp.constraints → 0 ≤ a x :=
```

```suggestion
    simp only [mem_feasibles] at hyp
```
You shouldn't need to ever unfold `feasibles` any more. I recommend also doing this at the start of the proof before you split the goals
Unresolving for my second sentence
Yeah, I haven't opened in IDE yet.
Now.

This and the result below should be in the namespace
```suggestion
lemma LinearProgram.feasibles_superset_of_constraints_subset {lp₁ lp₂ : LinearProgram K P}
```
Why not do these before the `constructor` too, to save doing them twice?
This should include a discussion about the meaning of  "linear" in linear program vs the use of `linear` in mathlib, and why it's actually `affine`.

The doc-string doesn't match the content. There's no `a` or `b` there, so don't confuse matters by introducing them.

Instead say that the values of the constraints must be non-negative.

I don't particularly like the design, with constraints and objective bundled together. The feasibility of constraints makes no mention of the objective, and the design should allow talking about this without an objective. Please separate these.

Would you be more happy with the following definitions?
```
def LinearProgramFeas (R : Type*) {V : Type*} (P : Type*)
    [LinearOrderedRing R] [AddCommGroup V] [Module R V] [AddTorsor V P] :=
  List (P →ᵃ[R] R)

structure LinearProgramOpt (R : Type*) {V : Type*} (P : Type*)
    [LinearOrderedRing R] [AddCommGroup V] [Module R V] [AddTorsor V P] where
  constraints : LinearProgramFeas R P
  objective : P →ᵃ[R] R
```

Why not two structures, one extending the other?

Presumably for the "just the constraints" version, you then want definitions `satisfiable_at` and `satisfiable`, with lots of lemmas about how these interact with list operations (e.g. adding/erasing etc constraints).
Why are you asking for `LinearOrderedField`? I think this definition should allow `K = Int`.

I am skeptical about making this a `List` rather than a `Set`. One is not actually going to do computation with this type: any meaningful algorithm will require a much more complicated data structure.

I think I remember Martin expressing some objections to situations with infinitely-many constraints, as those tend not to appear in linear programming. That would rule out `Set`, and prohibiting duplicates or permutations isn't particularly interesting since the constraints can still be redundant.
Happy to hear Martin's take on this, or for someone to click "resolve" as is.

If finiteness is really the thing of interest though, you could argue that what we actually want is the type of convex sets built from finitely many half planes; either non-constructively via an existential, or constructively via a Finset and a proof that removing any one element increases the size of the feasible set.
Can you induct on Finsets?
`Finset.cons_induction`

About the second part of your comment, redundant constraints are often a thing that we have to deal with (because they come from the ambient problem in the LP). So we probably shouldn't have the proof obligation that says "removing a constraint strictly increases the feasible set"

I remember we talked about something related to the choice `List` vs `Set` in the LP definition, but I don't remember what the discussion was about. Right now, I cannot think of any objection to infinitely many constraints in the LP definition. Of course, many results will be restricted to finite settings.

If you allow arbitrarily many conditions, what is the guarantee that you even have a polytope with well defined planes, vertices, faces etc. For example, you could define the set of all tangents to a sphere or an ellipsoid by parametrization as constraints. Would it still be a linear program in any meaningful sense?
You are right. Just one comment (not contradicting to your suggestion); all point on the sphere would be vertices.

> About the second part of your comment, redundant constraints are often a thing that we have to deal with (because they come from the ambient problem in the LP). So we probably shouldn't have the proof obligation that says "removing a constraint strictly increases the feasible set"

I don't think this claim necessarily holds merit; finsets are not allowed to hold duplicates, and have a proof obligation to this end; but that doesn't stop you from writing `{1, 1, 2, 2}`. You only have to deal with the proof obligation if you call `Finset.mk` directly.

Arguably this "Finset of non-redundant affine constraints" object deserves it's own `ConvexPolytope` object.
Though another reasonable approach might be to discard the proof obligation and work with the quotient of the type by equality of feasible spaces

A redundant LP need not have identical constraints. It just needs to be a linear combination of other constraints. I am not sure I see the value in doing, let's say Gaussian elimination on constraints, to extract independent ones makes sense every time an LP is defined. In computer science and also possibly OR, redundant constraints are a fact of life that have to be dealt with algorithmically, and so one often constructs what Mathlib devs might call API lemmas to deal with these cases.

When I think about it, having infinitely many conditions is less weird than having infinitely many variables. Given that Mathlib maintainers want the variable space to be general, we should also make the condition space general. Defining conditions as a list (or a multiset, or a finite set) of any type will be bad for LP duality, unless we change the type of `P` along with it.

pullRequest.title: feat: Define linear programs
